metadata.title: Journal Pre-proof Heart Block in Patients with Coronavirus disease 19: A case series of 3 Patients infected with SARS-COV-2. Title: Heart Block in Patients with Coronavirus disease 19: A case series of 1 3 Patients infected with SARS-COV-2. Corresponding author: Tala Eneizat Mahdawi MD

body_text.text: Province, China [1] . By the end of January, 2020, the WHO declared the 28 outbreak of SARS-CoV-2 a Public Health Emergency of International 29 Concern [2] . Respiratory illness remains the main clinical manifestation of 30 COVID 19 but involvement of other systems including the cardiovascular 31 system has been well documented. It is estimated that up to 19.7% of 32 patients were noted to have cardiac injury based on literature from Wuhan, 33 China [3, 4] . Cardiac arrythmia has been reported in 16.7% of patients 34 without further specification [2] . Effects on the conduction system have not 35 been reported besides a few case reports [5, 6] . We present a case series On day six of admission, the patient was noted to have bradycardia.

Telemetry revealed a second-degree AV block with 2:1 conduction ( Figure   116 3.A). These episodes of AV block lasted for less than a minute but recurred Disease of the AV node happens occasionally in severely ill patients [7] . infections. [8, 9] In our case series, neither troponin elevation nor ventricular Lyme carditis, proximal to the bundle of HIS [10] . Further electrophysiologic 184 studies from case reports support this pattern of involvement [11, 12] . The 185 mechanism of AV nodal block is believed to be due to an inflammatory 186 process secondary to direct invasion of heart tissue by Borrelia burgdorferi 187 with almost complete resolution of AV block in up to 6 weeks. [13, 14]

FIGREF0.text: 2019 a novel coronavirus, SARS-COV-2 was identified as the 26 pathogen causing coronavirus disease 2019 (Covid-19) in Wuhan, Hubei27

FIGREF1.text: 36 of 3 patients with otherwise normal cardiac structure and function and 37 3 without prior cardiac history who were admitted to the intensive care unit 38 with COVID-19 and developed periods of complete heart block during their 39 clinical course without any other identifiable etiology. We believe this is a 40 novel effect of COVID-19, and thus it is important for clinicians to be aware 41 of this potential manifestation of disease.

FIGREF2.text: one is an 82-year-old male with a medical history significant for 45 hypertension and prior stroke who presented to the emergency department 46 complaining of shortness of breath and a dry cough for four days. On 47 arrival to the emergency department, he was noted to be in severe hypoxic 48 respiratory distress requiring immediate endotracheal intubation. Chest x-49 ray revealed patchy bilateral parenchymal opacities. Clinical presentation 50 was highly suspicious of COVID-19. A nasopharyngeal swab test for 51 COVID-19 on real-time reverse transcriptase-polymerase chain reaction 52 (PCR) assay was positive. His initial lab work up was remarkable for 53 lymphopenia (779 cells/mm3), elevated BUN/Cr (22.7), mild transaminitis 54 (AST 115 U/L and ALT 83 U/L), electrolytes were all within normal limits , 55 and elevated inflammatory markers (CRP 12.27 mg/dl, procalcitonin 0ml. Electrocardiogram (ECG) on presentation showed normal sinus 59 rhythm at a rate of 82 bpm, normal intervals, normal axis, and no ST-T 60 wave changes (figure 1). This was unchanged from prior outpatient ECGs.

FIGREF3.text: endotracheal intubation and on stable ventilator settings, the 63 patient was noted to be in complete heart block on telemetry.Figure 2.A 64 shows an electrocardiogram performed at this time. Minimal change in 65 heart rate was noted and there were no pauses. Further work up included 66 normal thyroid function, serial negative cardiac biomarkers, and normal 67 cardiac function on echocardiogram. Review of medication list was 68 remarkable for absence of AV node blocking agents. He was sedated with 69 propofol and dexmedetomidine which were both discontinued and yet the 70 patient continued to manifest with heart block with a narrow escape rhythm 71 with stable hemodynamics for 6 days (Figure 2.B). These ECGs showed 72 intermittent Wenckebach pattern and escape-capture Wenckebach 73 consistent with AV nodal disease. His respiratory illness continued to 74 worsen requiring proning on multiple occasions to improve his 75 Oxygenation.

FIGREF4.text: course was further complicated by catheter associated 78 bloodstream infection with staphylococcus epidermidis. Unfortunately, his 79 hypoxic respiratory failure continued to worsen and his inflammatory 80 markers remained elevated. His family eventually elected to focus on 81 comfort measures and the patient passed away on hospital day 16. is a 55-year-old male with no significant medical history who 88 presented to the emergency department with a dry cough and a sore throat 89 for one week. A nasopharyngeal swab was positive for COVID 19 and the 90 patient was sent home to self-quarantine. He presented 6 days later with 91 progressive shortness of breath. His initial vitals were significant for a fever 92 of 101.1F, tachypnea and an oxygen saturation of 85%. He developed 93 persistent hypoxemia despite oxygen therapy requiring intubation. Initial

FIGREF5.text: dl, LDH of 666 U/L, and CRP 22.9 mg/dl). His other laboratory work-up 97 was within normal limits including a normal troponin T. His initial ECG 98 showed a heart rate of 90 bpm with a right bundle branch block and as well 99 as ST depressions in the inferior leads that were present at his baseline. 100 Chest x-ray revealed bilateral ground-glass opacities. He completed a 5-101 day course of Hydroxychloroquine and Azithromycin for COVID 19.

FIGREF6.text: was complicated by shock on day 2 of admission requiring 104 vasopressor support. He progressed into multiorgan failure and developed 105 acute kidney injury, hepatic failure as well as elevated troponin level (peak 106 troponin T level was 1.35 ng/ml). Due to sudden change in clinical status, 107 a bed side echocardiogram was done which revealed right heart strain and 108 McConnell's sign concerning for pulmonary embolism. The patient received 109 Tissue plasminogen activator (TPA) with improvement in hemodynamic 110 status. He was initiated on continuous renal replacement therapy for his 111 worsening kidney function. A repeat echocardiogram one day after TPA 112 administration revealed improved RV function.

The patient continued to have 2:1 block for 3 days 119 intermittently despite removing all sedation. At that time the patient was not 120 on any AV nodal blocking agents. 121 122AV block resolved and the patient was successfully extubated onDay 15   123    and was discharged to a long-term acute care hospital.

FIGREF9.text: three is a 43-year-old male with no significant medical history who 127 initially presented with shortness of breath, fever, myalgias and diarrhea for 128 five days. On arrival to the Emergency department, patient was noted to be 129 febrile with a temperature of 101 F, tachycardic with a heart rate of 105 130 bpm as well as hypoxemic with an oxygen saturation of 88% on room air.

FIGREF10.text: Chest x-ray revealed bilateral infiltrates. Initial lab work-up revealed mildly . ECG on admission showed normal sinus rhythm at 74 bpm, 135 normal intervals, normal axis and absence of ischemic findings.136 137 His course was complicated by progressive hypoxemia despite maximal 138 oxygen therapy requiring endotracheal intubation, paralysis and proning. 139 On day 6, his Nasopharyngeal swab tested positive for SARS-COV-2 by 140 PCR. He completed a 5-day course of Hydroxychloroquine and 141 Azithromycin. His course was further complicated by a superimposed 142 bacterial infection requiring broad spectrum antibiotics.

FIGREF11.text: 22 of admission another repeat test for SARS-COV-2 was still 145 positive. On day 24 of admission, patient was noted to be in intermittent 146 complete heart block on telemetry for less than 24 hours (Figure 3.B). His 147 inflammatory markers at that time remained elevated including CRP (34.4 148 mg/dl), LDH (318 U/L), Ferritin (1237 ng/ml), Fibrinogen (954 mg/dl), and 149 D-dimer (3.8 ug/mlFEU), electrolytes were all within normal limits.

FIGREF13.text: Possible mechanisms for transient impairment include metabolic158 alterations, enhanced vagal tone due to pain, sleep, carotid sinus 159 manipulation during usual nursing and caring of patients, or medication 160 side effects. These multifactorial mechanisms tend to lead to intermittent 161 and often first or second-degree AV block. Higher grade AV block as 162 described previously in our clinical vignettes suggest another pathology of 163 AV conduction disturbance. 164 165 Underlying etiologies for new onset AV node disease include ischemic 166 cardiac disease, thyroid disease, anatomical disturbances, medications and 167

FIGREF14.text: 168 dysfunction was associated with AV block, suggesting either focused 169 involvement of the AV node or a secondary cause of AV block associated 170 with the critical illness and organ dysfunction. The nature of AV block in 171 these cases suggests the origin of block is in the AV node. The evidence 172 for this is that the escape rhythm tended to be narrow, similar to sinus in 173 morphology, and of adequate rate to support normal hemodynamics 174 without requiring temporary pacing. In addition, two patients showed 175 evidence of a Wenckebach pattern recorded during onset or resolution of 176 AV block, providing further evidence that the location of block was in the 177 AV node, and therefore suggest a benign prognosis of the atrioventricular 178 block. 179 180 Similar involvement of the conduction system has been previously 181 described with other infectious etiologies including but not limited to Lyme 182 carditis. Steers et al suggested a predilection for AV node involvement In183

FIGREF15.text: from the cytokine storm and/or direct invasion of the 192 cardiomyocytes. Inflammatory cells and SARS-COV-2 virus has been 193 identified in the myocardium in autopsy studies, suggesting direct invasion 194 of the heart in some cases [15]. The implication of development of AV block 195 during critical illness with SARS-COV-2 infection remains unknown. 196 Whether this will have permanent effects remains questionable, but the 197 resolution of AV block in all patients in this series without the need for 198 pacemaker placement suggests that these patients may not suffer long 199 term ill effects.

FIGREF16.text: also notable that we have observed several cases of severe sinus 203 bradycardia and sinus node dysfunction associated with SARS-COV-2 204 infection. We did not include these cases in this series as sinus bradycardia 205 may be a relatively common finding in patients who are intubated and 206 treated with sedatives. However, there may be an association if believe it is pertinent for clinicians to be aware of such worrisome 211 potential effect of SARS-COV-2 infection and thus our aim of this case 212 series is to create awareness of a possible effect of COVID19 on the 213 conduction system and encourage future investigations and studies to 214 further characterize this potential effects of this virus on the cardiac 215 conduction system.

FIGREF17.text: A, ECG of case one obtained on presentation demonstrating 301 normal sinus rhythm at a rate of 82 bpm with normal intervals, normal axis, 302 and no ST-T wave changes. B, ECG of case one on day 1 of admission 303 demonstrating complete heart block with an independent atrial rate at 80 304 bpm (blue arrow) and narrow complex escape ventricular rhythm at a rate 305 of 50 bpm (Red arrow).C, Case one on day 3 of admission demonstrates 306 escape-capture Wenckebach with a pattern of a conducted beat with a long 307 PR (blue arrows) followed by a dropped beat and then apparent 308 nonconduction of the subsequent P wave due to occurrence of a junctional 309 escape beat (red arrows). The significant variability of the R-R intervals and 310 association of shorter R-R intervals with P waves demonstrates presence 311 of some degree of AV conduction.

back_matter.text: 1.COVID 19 can potentially manifest with AV Block. The nature of AV block as seen in these cases suggests the origin of block is in the AV node. The evidence for this is that the escape rhythm tended to be narrow, similar to sinus in morphology, and of adequate rate to support normal hemodynamics.2.Whether AV node involvement in COVID 19 will have permanent effects remains unknown, but the resolution of AV block in these patients without the need for pacemaker placement suggests that they may not suffer long term ill effects.3.Future investigations and studies are needed to further characterize the potential effects of SARS-COV-2 on the cardiac conduction system.
